author: DAVID MEDDOWS
title: Snow forecast for Thredbo, Perisher, Armidale as cold front sweeps state | Travel | Travel News and Holiday Deals | | The
text:
A MASSIVE cold front sweeping across NSW on the weekend is set to bring icy conditions to much of the state with Sunday predicted to be the day to stay in bed.
Powered by freezing air from the Antarctic, the cold snap will really take hold on Sunday with top temperatures in Sydney not expected to exceed 14 in the city and 13 in the west.
And they’re sticking around.
Those chilly temperatures are expected to continue well into next week with temperatures not heading north of 15 in the city and 14 in the west until at least Thursday.
Further west the mercury will only reach six in the Blue Mountains on Sunday and will stay in that region for at least a few days after.
Armidale is expected to turn white this weekend. Source: News Corp Australia
Oberon could also get a dusting of snow. Source: Supplied
The freezing blast is also set to turn some areas of the state white with snow predicted to fall in the regional centre of Armidale and other parts of the Northern Tablelands, including Guyra, and also the Central Tablelands, with possible falls in Oberon and Bathurst.
Some of higher areas of the Northern Tablelands get at least one or two falls a year, but it’s rare for Armidale, which sits lower, to receive any.

And while there won’t be any snow in Sydney, you might need to pull out the thermals as temperatures are expected to reach a top of just 13 degrees on Sunday after a relatively mild 19 on Saturday.
The cold front also looks likely to bring some much needed relief to the Snowy Mountains where the ski resorts have been suffering from a lack of snow since the season began last month.
The ski fields in Perisher (pictured) and Thredbo have been struggling due to a lack of snow in the Snowy Mountains Picture: Perisher Source: Supplied
In Perisher, 25 lifts remain closed and only one black run — those for more advanced skiers and boarders — open. Five of 14 lifts are off at Thredbo, but many trails remain inaccessible due to poor snow cover.
But that’s all about to change if the predictions are to be believed.
MountainWatch says up to 30cm of fresh snow could fall across the mountains from Friday to Monday with another 30-40cm possible on Monday and Tuesday.
Up to 30cm of fresh snow could fall across the Snowy Mountains this weekend. Source: Supplied
Perisher Blue spokeswoman Samantha Hales said the resort was expecting a substantial dump this weekend.
“All reports and forecasts are predicting anywhere from 30-70cm, I guess we’ll just have to wait and see,” she said.
She said despite the poor natural snowfalls, the resort had invested heavily in snow-making equipment to ensure people were still able to ski.
“Perisher has invested around $25 million in automated snow-making over the past eight years which gives Perisher the most reliable snow conditions in Australia,” she said.
“With three of our four resort areas open there is plenty to offer people even when we have a slow start to the season.”
Good news for skiers as forecasts predicting anywhere from 30-70cm falls at Perisher Village. Source: Supplied
Bureau of Meteorology spokesman David Barlow said it was very difficult to predict the actual amount of snow that will fall because of the different variables involved.
But he did confirm there should be a significant dump in the area which should be music to the ears of resort operators.
Originally published as 30cm of fresh snow for ski resorts
